name: Aphids
description: Small, sap-sucking insects that cluster on new growth. They can be green, black, yellow, or pink.
symptoms: Yellowed or distorted leaves, sticky 'honeydew' on leaves, sooty mold growth, stunted plant growth.
organic_treatment: Spray with a strong jet of water to dislodge them. Introduce beneficial insects like ladybugs or lacewings. Apply insecticidal soap or neem oil.
chemical_treatment: Pyrethrin-based insecticides. Use sparingly to avoid harming beneficial insects.

name: Powdery Mildew
description: A common fungal disease that appears as white or gray powdery spots on leaves and stems.
symptoms: White, powdery patches on the upper surfaces of leaves. Leaves may yellow and dry out. Flowers can be distorted.
organic_treatment: Improve air circulation. Remove and destroy affected leaves. Spray with a solution of baking soda (1 tbsp per gallon of water) or use a milk spray (1 part milk to 9 parts water). Neem oil is also effective.
chemical_treatment: Fungicides containing sulfur or potassium bicarbonate. Apply according to label directions.

name: Spider Mites
description: Tiny, spider-like pests that are difficult to see with the naked eye. They thrive in hot, dry conditions.
symptoms: Fine webbing on the plant, tiny yellow or white spots on leaves (stippling), leaves may turn yellow or bronze and drop off.
organic_treatment: Increase humidity around plants. Use a strong spray of water to knock them off. Apply insecticidal soap or neem oil, ensuring to cover the undersides of leaves.
chemical_treatment: Miticide sprays. Be aware that many spider mite populations have developed resistance to common pesticides.

name: Root Rot
description: A serious fungal disease that attacks the roots of plants, typically caused by overwatering and poor drainage.
symptoms: Stunted growth, yellowing or wilting leaves, mushy, brown, and decaying roots. The plant may die suddenly.
organic_treatment: Prevention is key. Ensure well-draining soil and avoid overwatering. For potted plants, repot into fresh, sterile soil, trimming away any affected roots. For garden plants, improve soil drainage by adding organic matter.
chemical_treatment: Fungicide drenches can be used, but they are often a last resort and may not save a severely affected plant.
